questions.question: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.explanation: The condenser is typically located below the stage in a microscope.

questions.question: A 28-year-old sex worker presented with a painless ulcer on her vulva. On examination, inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following methods has been used to demonstrate the causative agent as per the given image?
questions.explanation: A painless genital ulcer with inguinal lymphadenopathy with the presence of spiral organisms on microscopy is suggestive of syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum, demonstrated by dark-field microscopy. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark-ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It uses reflected light and has a higher resolving power than the light microscope. Dark-field microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize Treponema pallidum when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present. Other options: Option B: Phase contrast microscopy improves the contrast to delineate structures within cells. A dark image is formed on a light background. Option C: Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorescent dyes like auramine-rhodamine to appreciate Mycobacterial species and malarial parasites. Option D: The electron microscope, invented by Ernst Ruska, helps in appreciating viral structures. It has a very high resolving power.

questions.question: Which among the following statements is false?

options.A: Muramic acid is present in prokaryotes
options.B: Mitotic division is present in eukaryotes
options.D: Multiple linear chromosomes are present in eukaryotes

questions.explanation: 80S ribosome is present in eukaryotes, while 70S ribosome is present in prokaryotes. 80S ribosome has subunits 60S and 40S, while 70S has subunits 50S and 30S. Prokaryote vs Eukaryote ribosome: 70S - 50S subunit - 5S RNA, 23S RNA, 30S subunit - 16S RNA. Prokaryotic ribosome: 60S subunit, 80S, 5S RNA, 5.8S, 28S RNA, 40S subunit, 18S RNA. Eukaryotic ribosome

questions.question: Which of the following methods will not help you visualize the bacterial cell wall? a) Fluorescence microscopy b) Electron microscopy c) Differential staining d) Simple staining
questions.explanation: The cell wall of bacteria cannot be seen with simple stains or direct light microscopy. The bacterial cell wall is present outside the plasma membrane and confers strength and shape to the cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans. The cell wall can be demonstrated by the following methods: Plasmolysis, Microdissection, Reaction with specific antibodies, Mechanical rupture of the cell, Differential staining procedures (e.g. Chance's method), Electron microscopy, Fluorescence microscopy.

questions.question: Which organism has the following cell wall structure? Cytoplasm - Lipoteichoic acid - Peptidoglycan cell wall - Plasma membrane
questions.explanation: The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of Gram-positive bacteria. The cell wall of bacteria provides shape and rigidity to the bacterial cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans. Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria have distinct cell wall features: Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid - Present, Absent; Thickness (Peptidoglycan) - Thicker, Thinner; Variety of amino acids - Few, Several; Aromatic and sulfur-containing amino acids - Absent, Present; Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane - Absent, Present. The cell wall in bacteria consists of a peptidoglycan layer, and in Gram-negative bacteria, an outer membrane with lipopolysaccharides. Other options: Option C: The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan). Option D: The cell wall of mycobacteria has mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid-fastness.

questions.question: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.explanation: Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion. Fimbriae, also called pili, are hair-like surface appendages that project from the cell surface as straight filaments. They are primarily seen in Gram-negative bacteria. They are polymers of pilin. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili - for adhesion - and sex pili - involved in bacterial conjugation. The functions of pili are given below: • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, where transfer of genetic material occurs. • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins. • Resistance to phagocytosis. Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response. • Twitching motility to bacteria.

questions.question: Pasteurization is done at
questions.explanation:
Pasteurization is done at 63 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. Pasteurization is the process of applying heat to milk to kill or stunt the growth of pathogenic bacteria. It was developed by Louis Pasteur. There are two methods for pasteurization: 
   • Holder method: Milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes 
   • Flash process: Milk is heated to 72°C for 15-20 seconds 
   Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. All the non-sporing pathogens (mycobacteria, brucellae, salmonellae) are killed in pasteurization. In the Holder method, heat-resistant Coxiella burnetii may survive. 
   Note: Louis Pasteur pioneered the techniques of pasteurization and sterilization. He also first advanced the germ theory of disease, which states that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. Furthermore, he disproved the theory of spontaneous generation and developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera. He is thus known as the father of modern microbiology.

questions.question: Which of the following methods of sterilization involves exposure to 100 °C for 20 minutes on 3 successive days?
questions.explanation: The method of sterilization that involves exposure at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days is called tyndallization or intermittent sterilization. Tyndallization, which utilizes steam, was used for sterilization of media containing gelatin, egg, serum, or sugar. This method may not kill spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles. Autoclaving has replaced this method now. Other options: Option A: Autoclaving involves heating at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15 psi. This is used for instruments, linen, laboratory ware. Option C: In pasteurization, milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. Option D: Heating an article at 80-85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days is called inspissation.

questions.question: Which of the following methods is used in the test shown below?
questions.explanation: The given image shows antibiotic sensitivity testing, which uses the lawn culture method. Lawn or carpet culture is the method in which a uniform surface growth of bacteria is present on the medium. It is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing (disc method) and bacteriophage typing. Stab culture (option D) is used for demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of bacteria, for maintenance of stock cultures. Streak culture (option A) is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. Stroke culture (option C) is used for providing pure growth of bacteria for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests. Other methods of culture include: Liquid culture - these are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. Pour plate culture - it gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.

questions.question: In which of the following organisms will the following phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.explanation: The given image shows Quellung reaction (halo around the bacteria) and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it. In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope. The anticapsular antibodies bind to the capsule and thus the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen. Capsulated organisms can be remembered with the following mnemonic: Some Streptococcus pneumoniae Killers Klebsiella pneumoniae Have Haemophilus influenzae Nice Neisseria meningitidis Capsules Cryptococcus neoformans.

questions.question: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences?

options.B: Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid - water

questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette of fever and hemoptysis in a labourer with the sputum smear showing acid-fast bacilli is suggestive of tuberculosis. Mycobacterium tuberculosis, detected on sputum smear, is appreciated by Ziehl-Neelsen staining, which would include carbol fuchsin - acid alcohol - methylene blue. Acid-fast bacteria (like MTB) in a stained Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) smear appear bright red against a blue background. Steps involved in ZN staining are: Place the sample on a slide and evenly spread it with rotational movement. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame. Apply carbol fuchsin stain and heat to fix it. Wash with water to remove excess stain. Decolourise with alcohol. Apply Methylene blue/Malachite green stain. Wash with water to remove excess stain. View under the microscope. Kinyoun modified the classical ZN staining such that heat fixing is not required. It is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. The slide is then washed with water and decolourized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope. Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.

questions.question: Given are a few case scenarios. The etiological agents of which of the following are microaerophilic?
questions.explanation: The aetiological agents of 1 and 2 are microaerophilic. The given case scenarios are: 1. A businessman with epigastric pain and a positive urease test has peptic ulcer disease, caused by Helicobacter pylori. It is microaerophilic. 2. Diarrhea caused by Gram-negative, small, spirally curved rod-like, motile bacilli describes Campylobacter jejuni. It is microaerophilic. 3. Rice-water diarrhea and Gram-negative curved bacilli with a 'fish-in-stream' appearance describe cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae. It is a facultative anaerobe. 4. Nasopharyngeal swab from a child with paroxysmal cough showing 'mercury drops' colonies describes Bordetella pertussis. It is an obligate aerobe. 5. Dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies on LJ medium describe Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is an obligate aerobe. Microaerophilic organisms grow best in low oxygen tension (2-10% oxygen). Note: Mycobacteria, such as M. bovis, can grow at oxygen tensions ranging from atmospheric to microaerophilic conditions. However, M. tuberculosis is an obligate aerobe.

questions.question: The given image shows a culture medium with lactose-fermenting and non-lactose-fermenting bacteria. Which of the following is not a component of the culture medium?
questions.explanation: The given image shows MacConkey agar. Cysteine is not a constituent of MacConkey agar. MacConkey agar is a differential or indicator medium. Lactose-fermenting organisms (e.g., E. coli) produce a pink color, and non-lactose-fermenting organisms (Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.) do not change the color. Contents of MacConkey agar include peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red, and sodium taurocholate (Mnemonic - PLANT). MacConkey agar is also a selective medium, i.e., the bile salts (sodium taurocholate) and dyes (neutral red) inhibit the growth of Gram-positive organisms and Gram-negative cocci.

questions.question: Which of the following is an enrichment medium?
questions.explanation: The image 'A' represents alkaline peptone water, which is an enrichment medium used for Vibrio cholerae. The other images represent: Image B - Blood agar with P. aeruginosa colonies; Image C - Loeffler's serum slope, which is used to isolate C. diphtheriae; Image D - Chocolate agar with F. tularensis colonies. Enrichment media suppress the growth of commensal bacteria and allow for the growth of certain organisms. These media are used for samples with mixed flora, e.g., stool. They are always liquid media, like alkaline peptone water. Other examples include tetrathionate broth and selenite-F broth for Salmonella sp. and Shigella sp. Enriched media are those to which additional nutrients, such as blood, serum, or egg, are added. They are used to grow bacteria with specific nutritional requirements. Examples include blood agar to test the hemolytic property of bacteria, chocolate agar for isolation of H. influenzae, and Loeffler's serum slope for isolation of C. diphtheriae.

questions.question: A microbiologist observes the following growth on a blood agar plate. Which of the following will not be the etiological agent?
questions.explanation: The above image shows a swarming type of growth on the agar plate. It will not be caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Swarming is the growth of motile bacteria in the form of a thin film on solid culture media. It is exhibited by the following: Gram-positive bacilli - Clostridium tetani (option A), Bacillus cereus (option D); Gram-negative bacilli - Proteus mirabilis; Gram-negative halophilic bacteria - Vibrio parahaemolyticus. Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.

questions.question: Which of the following principles is primarily used in polymerase chain reaction?

options.B: It can amplify small amounts of DNA
options.C: It can amplify small amounts of RNA

questions.explanation: The primary principle used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is the amplification of small amounts of DNA. PCR is an automated process in which a single or a few copies of a DNA piece is amplified to generate thousands to millions of copies of that particular DNA sequence. There are three basic steps involved in PCR: DNA extraction from microorganisms, amplification of extracted DNA - denaturation (95°C), primer annealing (55°C), extension (72°C), and gel electrophoresis of the amplified product. PCR is used in rapid diagnostic tests for infections (e.g., HIV DNA), forensic investigations, etc. The founder of PCR is Kary B. Mullis.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the reverse transcriptase enzyme used in RT-PCR correctly?
questions.explanation: The enzyme involved in RT-PCR is reverse transcriptase (RT) which has RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity. In reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), reverse transcriptase synthesizes DNA from the RNA template. RT-PCR can be used for the demonstration of poliovirus RNA, causing paralytic poliomyelitis, in CSF. It can also be used for the detection of viruses from nasopharyngeal swabs (SARS-CoV-2, H1N1). In real-time RT-PCR, fluorescent dyes or DNA probes are used to quantify the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. So, it can be used to quantify viral loads in HIV, hepatitis B, etc., and is also called quantitative PCR (qPCR).

questions.question: What are jumping genes known as?
questions.explanation: Jumping genes are also called transposons. Transposons are genetic elements that can move between chromosomal and extra-chromosomal DNA molecules. Insertion of a transposon leads to acquisition of new characteristics by the recipient DNA. Transposons contain several genes, including those necessary for their migration from one genetic locus to another. They may contain genes for specialised functions like antibiotic resistance. However, they do not contain genes for their replication. Jumping genes were discovered by Barbara McClintock and she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1983 for the same. Other options: Options A and B: The cytoplasmic carriers of genetic information are termed plasmids or episomes. Option D: A cosmid is a type of hybrid plasmid that contains a Lambda phage cos sequence. (Cos sites + plasmid = cosmids).

questions.question: In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer?
questions.explanation: You should use a sanitizer before and after examining the patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. The hands should be washed with soap and water thoroughly in case they are visibly soiled. Sanitization is the process through which pathogenic organisms are reduced to safe levels on inanimate objects to reduce the likelihood of cross-infections. It is a component of hand-hygiene, which is demonstrated by the image below. Before touching a patient, Before clean/aseptic procedure, After touching a patient, After body fluid exposure risk - Critical site with body fluid exposure risk. Note: Disinfectants like chlorhexidine and alexidine have a biguanide functional group. They are mostly used as oral disinfectants and hand products. They are bactericidal but not sporicidal. Mycobacteria are also resistant to these compounds.

questions.question: An orthopedician is performing the following procedure to visualize the anterior cruciate ligament in a patient. Which of the following will be used to sterilize the instrument used?
questions.explanation: The given image shows arthroscopy being performed. Arthroscopes are sterilized using plasma sterilization, which utilizes hydrogen peroxide. In plasma sterilization, radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapors are passed. This generates plasma, which contains free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. Plasma denatures all organisms and is used to sterilize arthroscopes and ureteroscopes. Sterilization control is monitored by Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus. Option A: Ethylene oxide has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity. It is used for sterilization of heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, suture materials, etc. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis. Option B: Gamma rays cause breakage of DNA. They destroy spores and vegetative cells, but are not effective against viruses. It is referred to as cold sterilization and is used in commercial plants to sterilize plastics, syringes, swabs. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus pumilius. Option D: Ultraviolet rays are used to sterilize biosafety cabinets, entryways, operation theaters, and laboratories.

questions.question: Detailed Explanations: This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage. Parts of microscope: Ocular lens (eye piece), Nose piece, Objective lens, Stage clip, Aperture, Diaphragm, Condenser, Light source, MARROW, Head, Arm, Mechanical stage, Coarse adjustment, Fine adjustment, Brightness adjustment. The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens. The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by Hans and Zacharias Janssen, uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.
